data.text/markdown:
Week 1: Introduction to Mathematical Modeling

IME775: Data Driven Modeling and Optimization

Learning Objectives

By the end of this session, you will be able to:
  • Define mathematical modeling and its role in decision-making
  • Identify the components of a mathematical model
  • Classify different types of models
  • Formulate simple optimization problems

What is Mathematical Modeling?

A mathematical model is a representation of a real-world system using mathematical concepts and language. It allows us to:
  • Analyze complex systems
  • Predict behavior under different conditions
  • Optimize decisions and outcomes
  • Communicate ideas precisely

Components of a Mathematical Model

  1. Decision Variables: What we can control
  2. Objective Function: What we want to optimize (minimize/maximize)
  3. Constraints: Limitations and requirements
  4. Parameters: Fixed values from the problem context

Example: Production Planning Problem

A factory produces two products: Product A and Product B.
Resource Product A Product B Available
Labor (hrs) 2 3 120
Materials (kg) 4 2 100
Profit ($) 50 40 -
Goal: Maximize profit while respecting resource constraints.

Mathematical Formulation

Decision Variables:
  • ||(x_1||) = units of Product A
  • ||(x_2||) = units of Product B
Objective Function: $||(\max Z = 50x_1 + 40x_2||)$ Subject to: $||(2x_1 + 3x_2 \leq 120 \quad \text{(Labor)}||)$ $||(4x_1 + 2x_2 \leq 100 \quad \text{(Materials)}||)$ $||(x_1, x_2 \geq 0 \quad \text{(Non-negativity)}||)$

Interactive Exercise

Use the sliders below to explore different production quantities and see how they affect profit and constraint satisfaction.

Types of Mathematical Models

Type Characteristics Examples
Deterministic No uncertainty LP, Integer Programming
Stochastic Includes randomness Queuing, Simulation
Static Time-independent Portfolio optimization
Dynamic Time-dependent Inventory, Scheduling
Linear Linear relationships Transportation, Assignment
Nonlinear Nonlinear relationships Neural networks, SVM

Next Week

We will dive deeper into optimization basics and learn systematic methods for solving linear programming problems.
